funder.name: Ministry of Research, Innovation and Science

abstract: <jats:sec><jats:title>Premise of the Study</jats:title><jats:p>The detection of environmental <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">eDNA</jats:styled-content>) using high‐throughput sequencing has rapidly emerged as a method to detect organisms from environmental samples. However, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">eDNA</jats:styled-content> studies of aquatic biomes have focused on surveillance of animal species with less emphasis on plants. Pondweeds are important bioindicators of freshwater ecosystems, although their diversity is underestimated due to difficulties in morphological identification and monitoring.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Methods</jats:title><jats:p>A protocol was developed to detect pondweeds in water samples using <jats:italic>atpB</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>rbcL</jats:italic> and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ITS</jats:styled-content>2 markers. The water samples were collected from the Grand River within the rare Charitable Research Reserve, Ontario (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">RARE</jats:styled-content>). Short fragments were amplified using primers targeting pondweeds, sequenced on an Ion Torrent Personal Genome Machine, and assigned to the taxonomy using a local <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> reference library and GenBank.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Results</jats:title><jats:p>We detected two species earlier documented at the experimental site during ecological surveys (<jats:italic>Potamogeton crispus</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Stuckenia pectinata</jats:italic>) and three species new to the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">RARE</jats:styled-content> checklist (<jats:italic>P. foliosus</jats:italic>,<jats:italic> S. filiformis</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>Zannichellia palustris</jats:italic>).</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Discussion</jats:title><jats:p>Our targeted approach to track the species composition of pondweeds in freshwater ecosystems revealed underestimation of their diversity. This result suggests that <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">eDNA</jats:styled-content> is an effective tool for monitoring plant diversity in aquatic habitats.</jats:p></jats:sec>
title: Finding the pond through the weeds: <scp>eDNA</scp> reveals underestimated diversity of pondweeds
